steps.text: Construct buildings with preventive design for pest management.
Maintain building to prevent pest entry.
Construct a well-designed building for pest management.
Implement daily pest management programs.
Maintain awareness of federal and state regulations.
Design exterior with short grass, trimmed shrubs, paved access, proper drainage, and gravel strip.
Use proper engineering materials and framing.
Seal walls, use concrete or brick, and avoid hollow panel-type walls.
Install smooth, water-free roofs.
Use as few windows as possible with good lighting and tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows.
Block bird access to ledges.
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Use rodent bait stations where policy allows.
Form an inspection committee with highest company official as chairman and all department heads.

Set the primary goal to review existing activities and compile a list of deficiencies in Pest Control (PC), Operational Methods (OM), Personnel Practices (PP), Maintenance for Sanitation (M), and Cleaning Practices (C).
Wear identifiable uniforms and carry necessary tools during inspections.
Wear identifiable uniforms and carry necessary tools for inspections.
Thoroughly inspect all areas, looking in new places and recording defects.
Correct identified defects immediately.
Review notes and assign realistic correction dates.
Encourage plant-wide cooperation by rewarding good sanitation.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm for a fresh perspective.
Identify regulators of storability in postharvest systems.
Monitor stored products using visual inspection and tools like lights and traps.
Identify common insect pests in raw grain and processed food.
Select appropriate trap type based on environment (dusty, clean, hot, cold).
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility for interception or lure away pests.
Identify factors for determining trap placement.
Place traps on outer perimeter of facility.
Monitor trap catches and adjust placement as needed.
Interpret trap catches by looking for increases in numbers.
Create a pest management plan.
Implement monitoring and inspection strategies.
Apply structural modifications to keep out pests.
Use non-chemical control methods.
Apply chemical control in bulk seed storage.
Implement rodent control program.
Apply bird control methods.
Read the label of a pesticide container.
Identify food, food processing facilities, nonfood areas, and food areas.
Determine the type of residual application: general, spot, or crack and crevice.
Understand pesticide regulations at the federal and state levels.
Check for pesticide residues and tolerances.
Identify unapproved pesticides or residues above tolerance levels in food products.
Destroy adulterated food products.
Understand site-specific pesticide usage based on labels and regulations.
Ensure USDA approval for pesticides used in meat plants.
Follow safety guidelines to protect workers, facility employees, and food products.
Understand the life cycle of beetles and moths to identify infestations.
Identify moth species: Almond Moth, Indianmeal Moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, Mealmoth.
Determine infested food products.
Apply control methods: avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, fumigation.
Identify beetle species: Lesser Grain Borer, Cigarette Beetle, Drugstore Beetle, Confused Flour Beetle, Sawtoothed Grain Beetle, Merchant Grain Beetle, Foreign Grain Beetle.
Determine infested food products for beetles.
Identify pest: Foreign Grain Beetle.
Check for signs of high moisture.
Next pest: Cockroaches.
Identify cockroach species (German, American, Oriental, Brown-banded).
Look for signs of infestation: cast skins, egg cases, musty odor.
Implement control measures: sanitation and pesticides.
Check for other pests: Flies, Ants, Bees.
Identify rodent species and signs.
Understand rodent behavior for effective control.
Identify equipment types: compressed air sprayer, dusters, and space treating equipment.
Maintain compressor air sprayer: clean after use, check gaskets and valves regularly.
Select appropriate nozzle for compressed air sprayer.
Use dusters to apply dusts into voids, cracks, and burrows.
Choose appropriate method for space treating equipment: aerosols or fogs.
Follow safety precautions when using thermal fogging.
Produce thermal or mechanical fogs for use in warehouses.
Create mists with larger droplets than fogs (10-80 microns) and settle out more rapidly.
Apply Ultra Low Dosage (ULD) using specialized equipment and careful application to avoid hazards.
Wear respirators as indicated on the label, especially in enclosed spaces.
Choose appropriate respirator types: air-purifying or air-supplying.
Ensure respirators are approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
Maintain a proper fit and perform daily checks.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Wash respirators regularly.
Store respirators in a clean, protected place.

constraints.text: Use IPM approach integrating chemical, physical, cultural, and biological controls.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspections.
Implement a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Maintain proper moisture content, temperature, and access to prevent pest development.
Match trap type to the environment and adapt to changing temperature gradients throughout the year.
Determine appropriate trap placement based on facility size and pest presence.
Monitor trap catches regularly to ensure effective pest management.
Ensure applications are consistent with labeling (FIFRA law).
Apply pesticides only in permitted areas: food, nonfood, and food processing facilities.
Follow the correct type of residual application for each area.
Adhere to regulations regarding pesticide usage in food production.
Ensure safety of workers, facility employees, and food products.
Ensure proper identification of moth and beetle species before applying control methods.
Avoid cross-contamination between infested and uninfested food products.
Ensure proper identification of pests before implementing control measures.
Implement sanitation as part of cockroach control.
Recognize signs of rat and mouse presence, including droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, and tracks.
Inhalation is a serious hazard. Wear respirators as indicated on the label, especially in enclosed spaces.
Respirators for pesticides must be approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
A proper fit is essential.
Beards can interfere with a tight seal.
